Award.AwardTitle: CBMS Conference: Topological Data Analysis: Topology, Geometry and Statistics, May 23-27, 2016; Austin, TX
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a 5-day conference in topological data analysis at the University of Texas at Austin in the spring of 2016. Topological data analysis (TDA) has recently emerged as an active new field of research, which has generated great interest across mathematics, statistics, computer science, machine learning, and electrical engineering communities. TDA is being applied to image analysis, neuroscience, networks analysis, morphology, genetics,cancer research and other problems. The interdisciplinary nature of TDA naturally leads to the literature and the active researchers being scattered across different fields. This lack of a cohesive disciplinary home makes it difficult for junior researchers and in particular graduate students from statistics to obtain exposure to the field. The proposed workshop strives to fill this gap by focusing on tutorial and overview talks on topological data analysis and providing hands-on data analysis sessions. The conference will feature Professor Sayan Mukherjee from Duke University as the principal lecturer, and five additional invited speakers. The goal of the conference is to introduce graduate students and junior researchers to TDA, an active new field, which lies at the exciting intersection of topology, geometry, and statistics. This conference will also serve as an opportunity to foster research collaborations and chart possible future directions for research.

The program will provide an overview of how geometry and topology can be used for statistical inference. The proposed outline develops a framework for how geometry and topology is used for some common tasks in statistical inference including mixture models, modeling surfaces and shapes, extensions of spectral clustering, as well as machine learning aspects such as semisupervised learning. There will be some applied and data analysis aspects to the lecture where some common Topological Data Analysis codes will be used to model shape data, specifically computerized tomography (CT) scans of bones and organs. Applied aspects of the program will include applications of the methodology developed in quantitative genetics, statistical genetics, as well as computer vision applications. Another component of the program is focusing on the role of geometry in statistics. Some of the invited speakers such as Professors Rabi Bhattacharya and Susan Holmes will deliver lectures on this topics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CBMS regional conference on Topological Data Analysis: Topology, Geometry and Statistics was successfully held at the University of Texas at Austin from May 31-June 4, 2016. The conference featured Dr. Sayan Mukherjee from Duke University (Departments of Statistical Science, Mathematics, and Computer Science) as the principal lecturer. Dr. Mukherjee delivered a total of ten lectures (two lectures each day with one-hour and fifteen minutes’ length), which was complemented by five additional invited lectures delivered by Professors Rabi Bhattacharya, Susan Holmes, Ann Lee, Lek-Heng Lim and Yusu Wang. 

 

The conference was attended by 78 registered outside participants, and 15 additional local participants (graduate students from statistics, mathematics and other departments).  We offered travel support to 28 individuals. Of the 10 women to whom support was given 3 had to cancel last minute. So there were 7 women total who were supported. There were 19 men to whom we provided support. 18 of the 28 original funded participants were minorities.  Among all participants, out of n = 45 participants with identified gender, 15, i.e. 33% were women. We believe this is a good estimate of the overall proportion of women participants. 

 

A survey was carried for the evaluation of the program. We asked the participants to respond to the following questions on a scale 0 (worst) to 5 (best). We briefly summarize the results for n = 25 responses that were received.

1. Overall course rating: mean response 4.2?2. Course objectives were well explained: mean response 3.9

3. Course was well organized: mean response 4.5

4. Course prerequisites were well explained: mean response 3.8

5. Course materials were helpful: mean response 4.4.

6. What best describes your department/background? Responses were: statistics (16%), biostatistics (8%), mathematics (24%), applied math (16%), machine learning (12%), CS (8%), engineering (4%), other (12%).

7. What best describes your position?” Responses were: graduate student (72%), postdoc (4%), faculty (20%), other (4%). 

 

 

Topological Data Analysis (TDA) has recently emerged as an active new field of research, which has generated great interest across mathematics, statistics, computer science, machine learning, and electrical engineering communities. TDA is being applied to image analysis, neuroscience, networks analysis, morphology, genetics, cancer research and other problems. The interdisciplinary nature of TDA naturally leads to the literature and the active researchers being scattered across different fields. This lack of a cohesive disciplinary home makes it difficult for junior researchers and in particular graduate students from statistics to obtain exposure to the field.  Our workshop provided such a platform for junior researchers from diverse fields to interact with each other on TDA and foster potential research collaborations, and did an excellent job filling the gap by focusing on tutorial and overview talks on Topological Data Analysis and providing hands-on data analysis sessions provided by Dr. Mukherjee and five additional invited speakers who are all top researchers in the field. I believe we successfully achieved the goal of introducing many graduate students and researchers to an active new field, Topological Data Analysis, which lies at the exciting intersection of Topology, Geometry, and Statistics.

 

The conference attracted graduate students, junior faculty, and some established researchers from statistics, mathematics, machine learning, and other fields where TDA methods are of potential use. The conference provided a unique opportunity for participants across a variety of fields to interact and collaborate. In addition, the interdisciplinary nature of the workshop has strengthened connections between different departments such as the Department of Statistics & Data Sciences, and Department of Mathematics, Department of Computer Science, at The University of Texas at Austin.
